content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: is good.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: le jeu est intéressant

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Very nice reverse one! From the other comments I understand that it first had a description (I can imagine the challenge of describing this without making it too clear-cut), but as reverse puzzle, without description, it is a very unique and nice one. The different cases cover all different situations (so, I ran into a couple of errors along the way), and it gives that 'reverse puzzle' feeling because based on one or two of the test cases it is not yet clear, but based on all of them it becomes clear. Thanks for making this one!

From the description of the task it is not clear what to do. I am not a native English speaker, the phrase "grammatically correct" scares me. I figured out the problem, but the problem statement needs to be changed.

Constraints section
* Are the cases guaranteed to have a unique solution? If yes, please state it as a constraint.

* Please mention the lower limit of the length of [[s]] too.

Goal section / Cases
* More explanation is needed: rules about the order, letter case, how words should be classified into classes, etc.

For example, in the last validator, the expected output is "My mother is a teacher". "My teacher is a mother" is equally grammatically correct, isn't it?

Validator 3: the expected output is "I have no money at the moment". One may argue that "I have no moment at the money" to be grammatically correct, though the meaning is absurd.

Similarly with Test 4: how about "A mistake made you"?

The rules should make sure that this clash is a test on programming skills instead of a test on English grammar.

Game modes
* I don't think Reverse mode is appropriate for this clash.

Thanks.

The goal is what cause the confusion here. Actually there's a pattern in these test cases.
That's why I thought this will be good for reverse mode. If this is ok for reverse mode, then I can keep these test cases. What should I do here ?
I agree with you. I will the change the statement.

OK, now that grammar is out of the way, maybe Reverse mode is doable.

For Fastest Mode, please change "Find the pattern and solve it." to something like:

Given a string of space-separated words, form a reordered sentence so that:
• All the words which start with an uppercase letter come first.
• All the words which start with a lowercase letter come next, but in the reversed order.
• After rearranging the words, they are joined as a sentence with spaces separating the words.
• All words except for the first word in the reordered sentence are revised to start with a lowercase letter.

(The player is not supposed to guess the requirement in Fastest mode, hence a detailed explanation is needed.)

Input section
* Suggest to change "string" to "original string".

Output section
* Suggest to change "string" to "a string for the reordered sentence".

Thanks.
I'll go with the reverse mode and do the other suggested changes. Thanks for the feedback.
